'''Operation Minden''' was an offensive undertaken by [[United Nations]] (UN) forces during the [[Korean War]] between 8–12 September 1951, as part of a general advance to extend the Wyoming Line. Operation Minden was the precursor to the much larger [[Operation Commando]], which established the [[Jamestown Line]].
==Background==
By the autumn of 1951, [[I Corps (United States)|I Corps]] were positioned along the Wyoming Line, which was north of the [[38th parallel north|38th Parallel]]. The Wyoming Line served as an outpost line, and was an extension of the Kansas Line. The Wyoming Line ran roughly in an northeasterly arc from Hwachon Reservoir to the west of [[Chorwon]]. However, the curvature of the Imjin River, north of the small town of Choksong, meant that there was a salient extending southwards into the line.<ref name=Yu335>Yu 1973, p. 335–337</ref>
As part of an overall strategy to seize territory in order to strengthen his army's defensive position [[General (United States)|General]] [[James Van Fleet]], the commander of UN forces in Korea, ordered the removal of this salient in an operation codenamed "Minden".<ref name=McGibbon203>McGibbon 1996, p. 203–205</ref> The operation would primarily involve three elements of the [[1st British Commonwealth Division]], commanded by [[General]] [[James Cassels (British Army officer)|James Cassels]]; the [[28th Infantry Brigade (United Kingdom)|28th British Commonwealth Brigade]], the [[29th Infantry Brigade (United Kingdom)|29th British Commonwealth Brigade]] and the [[25th Canadian Infantry Brigade]].<ref name="Yu335"/>
==Operation==
The 28th British Commonwealth Brigade, including the 1st Battalions of the [[King's Shropshire Light Infantry]] and [[King's Own Scottish Borderers]] as well as [[3rd Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment]], crossed the Imjin River and established a bridgehead on 8 September.<ref name=Barclay91>Barclay 1954, p. 91–92</ref> Corresponding moves were made by flanking South Korean and United States units.<ref name=Maguire35>Maguire 1956, p. 35</ref>
The initial movement of the 28th Brigade was met with little resistance, with the exception of some minor skirmishing on the Australian front, during which three prisoners were captured.<ref name="Barclay91"/> With the bridgehead secure, two bridges were quickly erected by [[I Corps (United States)|I Corps]] engineers, with one bridge situated at the river crossing of the northerly road from Choksong.<ref name="Yu335"/>
The 29th Infantry Brigade and the 25th Canadian Infantry Brigade moved out of the bridgehead on 11 September. The 29th advanced to the northwest, while the Canadians moved off to the north. The 28th Brigade remained in reserve, guarding the newly constructed bridge. Like the 8 September crossing of the Imjin River, the movement of the 29th Brigade met with little resistance, although there were light casualties (12 killed) due to artillery fire.<ref name="Barclay91"/> The Canadians completed their movements with no casualties.<ref name="Maguire35"/> The operation concluded on 12 September, with the front line now running across the arc of the Imjin River, and firmly established nearly five kilometres north of the river.<ref name="McGibbon203"/>
==Aftermath==
There was some further adjustment of the line which was not completed until 14 September.<ref name="Maguire35"/> As part of this adjustment, B Company, of the 2nd Battalion of the [[Royal 22e Régiment|Royal 22<sup>e</sup> Régiment]], mounted offensive operations in order to seize some hills held by the Chinese, during which three Canadian soldiers were killed and ten wounded.<ref name="Yu335"/> The new front line was now much closer to the Chinese outposts than previously, necessitating regular patrols. Around 1,500 civilians also had to be evacuated from the area.<ref name="Barclay91"/>
The successful implementation of Operation Minden led to the more large scale [[Operation Commando]], which involved a substantial part of I Corps. Operation Commando was launched in October 1951 and resulted in the establishment of the [[Jamestown Line]].<ref name="Maguire35"/>
